projectBrief.name: Subflow
projectBrief.context: Series A startup ($5M raised). Building analytics dashboard for subscription businesses. Two competitors launched similar products last quarter. Investors expect demo-ready MVP in 12 weeks for Series B pitch.

client.name: David Chen
client.description: Technical background, first-time founder, under board pressure

projectBrief.risk: Investors expect live demo with real customer data in Week 12. No second chance.

weeks.title: Everything is Critical
weeks.context:
Monday morning. Kickoff call just ended. David sent a 23-page PRD over the weekend. You opened it Sunday night. It has everything: authentication, dashboard, integrations with Stripe, analytics engine, export to Excel, email notifications, user roles, API access.

The team is quiet in Slack. Olena asked "where do we start?" No one answered yet.

You have 47 user stories in the backlog. David said "it's all critical" three times during the call. Yana privately messaged you: "This is six months of work, not three."

signals.message: Just to confirm ‚Äî we're starting with the full scope, right? I know it's ambitious but investors need to see the vision.
I need clarity on priorities. If everything is critical, I'll design everything shallow. If we focus, I can go deep on 3-4 flows. Your call.
(no message)
I'm excited! When do we get designs? I can start on login page at least.

weeks.situation: The backlog is overwhelming. The team needs direction. David expects everything. You know "everything" means nothing gets done properly. No one has challenged David yet.

options.title: Accept full scope
options.description: Tell the team we'll try to deliver everything, start parallel work across all features.
options.shortConsequence: Team will feel trusted but overwhelmed

consequences.immediate: Team starts working on everything at once. Maksym begins login page. Olena starts designing multiple flows simultaneously. Yana begins database architecture for all features. Everyone is busy, but no one is focused. By Friday, you have 12 things in progress, nothing complete.
consequences.hidden: Week 4: Yana will tell you half-built features are blocking each other. Week 6: Team burnout begins.

options.title: Push back now
options.description: Schedule call with David, present 6-month timeline reality, negotiate scope reduction.
options.shortConsequence: Risk early conflict but gain clarity

consequences.immediate: David is defensive initially but respects the honesty. You spend 2 days creating realistic timeline. David agrees to cut 40% of scope. Team is relieved and focused. You lose 2 days but gain 3 weeks of focused work.
consequences.hidden: Week 8: David will second-guess this decision when competitors launch features you cut.

options.title: Build "MVP within MVP" silently
options.description: Agree publicly, but guide team to focus on core 3 features, keep others as "in progress."
options.shortConsequence: Team gets focus, but David expects everything

consequences.immediate: You tell team privately to focus on dashboard, Stripe integration, and analytics. Publicly, you keep David updated on "progress" across all features. Team has clarity. David stays optimistic. But the gap between expectation and reality is growing.
consequences.hidden: Week 9: David will discover the gap during board demo. Too late to course-correct strategically.

options.title: Request 2-day sprint zero
options.description: Postpone start, do estimation workshop with team, present timeline to David Friday.
options.shortConsequence: Lose 2 days but get realistic plan

consequences.immediate: Team spends Tuesday-Wednesday estimating properly. You present realistic 18-week timeline to David on Friday. He's shocked but appreciates transparency. You renegotiate: 12-week MVP with phase 2 roadmap. Team feels heard and realistic about timeline.
consequences.hidden: Week 11: You'll have 1 week buffer. It will save the project when Stripe API breaks.

weeks.title: The Design Bottleneck
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Olena has been quiet all week. You checked in yesterday. She said she's "working on design system first ‚Äî otherwise we'll have inconsistent UI later." She's right. But Maksym has been idle for three days. He keeps asking "when can I start coding?"

Yana started backend architecture. She's not waiting for designs. But frontend is blocked.

It's Thursday afternoon. David messaged: "Can I see designs tomorrow?"

signals.message: I need another week for design system. Buttons, inputs, colors, spacing. Otherwise Maksym will build inconsistent UI and we'll refactor forever.
I'm literally just sitting here. Can I at least build the login page? I don't need full designs for that.
Backend structure is ready. I'm moving to Stripe integration. Let me know when frontend is unblocked.
Quick sync tomorrow at 10 AM? Want to see where we are. Investors are asking questions.

weeks.situation: Olena's approach is right long-term, but you're losing velocity. Maksym is frustrated. David wants to see progress. You have a call tomorrow with nothing visual to show.

options.title: Support Olena fully
options.description: Tell David design system is foundational, push the sync to next week, protect Olena's timeline.
options.shortConsequence: Right decision, but no visible progress

consequences.immediate: David is frustrated but trusts you. Olena finishes design system by next week. It's beautiful and consistent. But you've lost 2 weeks of frontend development. Maksym's enthusiasm is fading. The team questions if you can meet the deadline.
consequences.hidden: Week 10: Perfect UI will impress investors during demo. This investment pays off.

options.title: Push Olena to deliver something
options.description: Ask her to skip design system, design 2-3 screens by tomorrow, system can wait.
options.shortConsequence: Short-term progress, long-term inconsistency

consequences.immediate: Olena works overnight, delivers 3 screen designs. David is happy. Maksym starts coding immediately. But UI components are inconsistent. Week 6: you'll spend 2 weeks refactoring frontend because buttons, spacing, and colors are all different across screens.
consequences.hidden: Week 6: Refactoring will cost 2 weeks. UI bugs will haunt you until launch.

options.title: Unblock Maksym with rough sketches
options.description: Tell Olena to give Maksym low-fi wireframes, he builds basic version, she refines later.
options.shortConsequence: Parallel work, but possible rework

consequences.immediate: Olena gives Maksym wireframes in 2 hours. He starts building with placeholder styles. Progress visible. Olena continues design system work in parallel. Some rework needed later, but not catastrophic. David sees movement. Team feels productive.
consequences.hidden: Week 8: You'll spend 1 week on visual refactoring. Not ideal, but manageable.

options.title: Show David backend progress
options.description: Skip design demo, show him API architecture, database schema, technical foundation.
options.shortConsequence: He might not understand it

consequences.immediate: David joins call. You screenshare database diagrams and API documentation. He nods politely but looks confused. After the call, he messages his co-founder: "Not sure they're making real progress." His trust drops. Team doesn't feel validated.
consequences.hidden: Week 7: David will micromanage more after this. Extra meetings, status updates.

weeks.title: The Surprise Feature
weeks.context:
You made your choice on the design bottleneck. Things are moving now. Maksym is coding. Yana is deep in Stripe integration. Andriy is writing test plans.

Friday morning. You're reviewing sprint progress. Feeling cautiously optimistic.

Then David posts in team channel. Not a DM. Public message. "Talked to potential customer yesterday. They need CSV import for historical data. Without it, they can't migrate from current tool. This is a dealbreaker."

The room goes cold. CSV import wasn't in the original scope. Yana responds immediately: "That's 2-3 weeks of work. Parsing, validation, error handling, UI for upload."

David replies: "But it's just reading a file, right?"

signals.message: I know we didn't plan this, but customer feedback is gold. We can't lose our first pilot user because of a missing feature.
CSV parsing is complex. Bad data, different formats, special characters. Then validation, rollback if it fails. Not a simple feature.
I can build the upload UI in a day. But backend processing is Yana's call.
Do we have designs for error states? Upload progress? File format requirements screen? This needs UX work.

weeks.situation: David just added 2-3 weeks of work publicly. Team is waiting for your response. He framed it as "customer need" so it's hard to refuse. But you have 9 weeks left and already tight scope.

options.title: Accept it, adjust timeline
options.description: Tell David yes, but push back the deadline OR cut other features. Make trade-off explicit.
options.shortConsequence: He might refuse, but it's honest

consequences.immediate: You schedule 1-on-1 with David. Present two options: push demo to Week 14, or cut user management feature. He's uncomfortable but chooses to cut user management. Team appreciates your backbone. Client relationship stays strong. But you'll demo without user roles.
consequences.hidden: Week 12 demo: Investor will ask 'Where's user management?' David will have to explain.

options.title: Say yes, absorb it somehow
options.description: Tell team to "make it work," hope for overtime or shortcuts.
options.shortConsequence: Team will burn out or quality drops

consequences.immediate: Team works overtime. CSV import gets built in 10 days through nights and weekends. Feature works but code quality is poor. Maksym burns out by Week 7. Yana is resentful. Tech debt accumulates. The feature is fragile and will break during demo.
consequences.hidden: Week 7: Maksym will need week off. Week 9: CSV import will crash during board demo.

options.title: Negotiate MVP version
options.description: Propose: support only one CSV format, no validation UI, manual error handling for pilot.
options.shortConsequence: Technical debt, but faster

consequences.immediate: David agrees to "basic version." Yana builds it in 5 days ‚Äî one format, minimal validation, no error UI. Customer can use it but it's fragile. Tech debt created but timeline protected. Team feels you found middle ground. Feature exists but isn't production-ready.
consequences.hidden: Week 8: CSV import will cause integration bugs. Week 12: Still unstable at demo.

options.title: Challenge the customer need
options.description: Ask David: is this pilot user committed? Or "interested"? Can they start without import?
options.shortConsequence: Might seem like you're blocking sales

consequences.immediate: David admits customer is "very interested" but not committed yet. You propose: launch without CSV, add it in Phase 2 if they convert. David reluctantly agrees. Team relieved. But 2 weeks later, customer goes with competitor who has CSV import. David loses faith in your judgment.
consequences.hidden: Week 6: David will override your decisions more. Micromanagement increases.

weeks.title: The Silent Blocker
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Olena has been quiet all week. You checked in yesterday. She said she's "working on design system first ‚Äî otherwise we'll have inconsistent UI later." She's right. But Maksym has been idle for three days. He keeps asking "when can I start coding?"

Yana started backend architecture. She's not waiting for designs. But frontend is blocked.

It's Thursday afternoon. David messaged: "Can I see designs tomorrow?"

signals.message: Yeah, I thought I'd wait for the real endpoint. Mock data feels like double work. But I can switch if you want.
I'm blocked on Stripe webhook testing. Can't move forward until I get test account approved. Waiting on David.
Stripe test account? I thought we had that. Let me check. Might be tomorrow.
(no message, but his Jira tasks are all marked "Waiting for dev")

weeks.situation: Maksym lost 3 days waiting for an endpoint that won't be ready for another week. Yana is blocked on external approval. The sprint is derailing. No one escalated early. Everyone thought it would resolve itself.

options.title: Let it slide, focus on next sprint
options.description: Accept the loss, don't make drama, reset expectations for next week.
options.shortConsequence: Team learns nothing about early escalation

consequences.immediate: You decide not to make a big deal of it. Sprint ends with minimal output. Team resets for next week. But the pattern continues ‚Äî people wait too long to escalate blockers. Week 7 will have the same issue, costing you another 3 days.

options.title: Implement daily standups
options.description: Require 15-min daily sync to catch blockers early.
options.shortConsequence: Adds overhead, might feel like micromanagement

consequences.immediate: You announce daily standups starting Monday. Maksym rolls his eyes slightly. Yana is neutral. Team feels like you don't trust them. But blockers do get surfaced faster. Week 6: you catch a critical API issue 2 days earlier because of standups.

options.title: Create "blocked" protocol
options.description: Establish rule: if blocked >4 hours, escalate immediately, no shame.
options.shortConsequence: Cultural change, takes time to adopt

consequences.immediate: You create a Slack channel #blockers and set the rule: blocked >4 hours = post there. Maksym and Yana agree it's reasonable. Takes 2 weeks for team to adopt the habit, but by Week 7 they're escalating early. You save 5 days across remaining weeks.

options.title: Have 1-on-1s with Maksym and Yana
options.description: Talk privately about communication breakdown, no team blame.
options.shortConsequence: Addresses symptoms, not system

consequences.immediate: You have separate calls with Maksym and Yana. Both are receptive and apologetic. They commit to better communication. It works for this sprint, but Week 8: Olena has the same issue with a design blocker she doesn't escalate. The system didn't change.

weeks.title: The Quiet Rebellion
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Created a "blocked" protocol. Team agreed in principle. Maksym apologized, said it won't happen again.

Week starts normal. Yana unblocked, now working on CSV import backend. Maksym is catching up on dashboard. Olena delivered final designs for analytics page. Andriy started exploratory testing on dev environment.

Thursday morning. Andriy posts in team chat: "Found 12 bugs in dashboard. Critical ones: data doesn't refresh, filters don't work, date range breaks on edge cases."

Maksym responds: "Yeah, I know. Those are tracked. Will fix after I finish analytics page."

Andriy replies: "But demo is in 7 weeks. If we don't fix now, they pile up."

Maksym doesn't respond. You check his tasks. He's working on new features, not fixing bugs. You message him privately. He says: "New features are more important. Bugs can wait."

signals.message: Should I keep testing or wait for fixes? I'm finding issues faster than they're getting resolved.
Let's do bugs in cleanup week. Right now I need to ship features or we won't have anything to demo.
For what it's worth, I agree with Maksym. We're not feature complete. Bugs are inevitable.
I'm seeing bugs in designs I delivered. It looks broken. This will reflect poorly in demo.

weeks.situation: There's a philosophical split. Maksym and Yana want feature velocity. Andriy and Olena want quality. Both are right. You have 7 weeks. If you slow down for bugs now, you might not finish features. If you ignore bugs, demo will look broken.

options.title: Feature freeze, fix bugs
options.description: Stop new development for 1 week, clean up existing work.
options.shortConsequence: Quality improves, but features delayed

consequences.immediate: You announce feature freeze. Maksym is frustrated but complies. Team spends full week on bugs. Dashboard becomes stable. By Friday, 10 of 12 bugs fixed. Demo quality improves significantly. But you're now 1 week behind on features. Week 9: you'll have to cut something.

options.title: Continue features, accept bugs
options.description: Tell Andriy to log issues, fix them in final weeks.
options.shortConsequence: Technical debt grows, might not have time later

consequences.immediate: You tell Andriy to keep logging bugs, you'll have "cleanup sprint" before demo. Maksym is relieved and moves fast on features. By Week 8: 47 bugs logged. Week 11: you have 3 days to fix them all. 23 bugs still open at demo. Product feels unstable.

options.title: Parallel tracks
options.description: Maksym does features, Andriy fixes critical bugs himself (basic frontend changes).
options.shortConsequence: Andriy oversteps role, might create conflicts

consequences.immediate: You ask Andriy to fix "simple" bugs himself ‚Äî button styling, text changes. He agrees but struggles with React code. His fixes introduce 3 new bugs. Maksym discovers this Week 7 and is upset: "Who changed my code?" Team tension increases.

options.title: Negotiated ratio
options.description: Each sprint: 70% features, 30% bug fixes. Compromise.
options.shortConsequence: Neither side fully happy, but balanced

consequences.immediate: You propose 70/30 split. Maksym isn't thrilled but accepts. Andriy feels heard. Progress continues steadily. Bug count stays manageable (~15 by Week 10). Demo quality is acceptable but not perfect. Team feels the compromise was fair.

weeks.title: The Founder's Doubt
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Maksym wasn't thrilled but accepted it. Andriy felt heard. Bugs are getting fixed, features are moving slower but steadier.

Mid-week. David schedules 1-on-1 with you. Unusual. He's normally in group chats. Call starts. He's not his usual energetic self.

"I've been thinking. Maybe we're building the wrong thing. I talked to three more customers this week. They all want different features. One wants Slack integration. Another wants API access. Third one wants white-labeling."

He pauses. "What if we're too narrow? Should we pivot?"

You're six weeks in. Half the budget spent. Demo in six weeks. And he's questioning the core product.

signals.message: Don't tell the team yet. But I'm genuinely unsure. Competitor launched white-label version yesterday. We look limited.
CSV import is done. Moving to analytics calculation engine. Should be ready by Monday.
Designs for settings page are ready for review. Let me know when you have 15 min.
Dashboard is looking good. Fixed 8 bugs this week. Can we review it together tomorrow?

weeks.situation: David is having a crisis of confidence. The team is executing well, unaware of his doubts. If you tell them, morale collapses. If you don't, you might be building the wrong thing. You have no authority to override his strategic decisions.

options.title: Validate his concerns
options.description: Agree that pivoting might be right, help him explore alternatives, pause development.
options.shortConsequence: Team stops, loses 2+ weeks, might never recover

consequences.immediate: You tell David his concerns are valid. You pause sprints to explore pivot options. Team is confused and demotivated. You spend 2 weeks on customer interviews and competitor analysis. Conclusion: original direction was correct. You've lost 2 weeks and team trust. Timeline unrecoverable.

options.title: Challenge the pivot
options.description: Tell him changing direction now is suicide, remind him of investor demo, push back.
options.shortConsequence: Might damage relationship, but protect timeline

consequences.immediate: You tell David bluntly: "Pivoting now kills the company. We're 50% done. Demo is in 6 weeks. Investors won't fund a team that can't execute." He's taken aback but respects the directness. Team continues. But David questions your judgment going forward. Week 9: he'll override one of your decisions.

options.title: Propose compromise
options.description: Build core product as planned, add "API access" as stretch goal if time allows.
options.shortConsequence: Sounds reasonable, but probably no time

consequences.immediate: You suggest continuing core product but exploring API access as Phase 2. David agrees. Team continues unaware. Week 10: you realize there's zero time for API. David is disappointed. Feels you promised something you couldn't deliver. Trust damaged.

options.title: Buy time
options.description: Ask him to commit to current plan until Week 9, then decide. Give product a chance.
options.shortConsequence: Delays decision, but keeps team moving

consequences.immediate: You tell David: "Let's commit until Week 9. By then we'll have working product and real data on whether it resonates." He agrees reluctantly. Team continues focused. Week 9: product looks good, David's doubts fade. Crisis averted. But you spent emotional energy managing his anxiety.

weeks.title: The Overworked Developer
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. David agreed reluctantly. He said: "Okay, but if it's not working by Week 9, we pivot." Fair enough. You didn't tell the team about this conversation.

Week continues. Features are coming together. Dashboard works. Analytics calculations are running. CSV import is functional. Olena finished most designs. Andriy is testing.

Friday, 7 PM. You're about to close laptop. Maksym posts in team chat: "Pushed final changes for analytics page. Going offline. See you Monday."

You open dev environment to check. The page loads. But something feels off. You test a few scenarios. Date filters break. Data doesn't match dashboard. Export button does nothing.

You message Maksym: "Hey, found some issues on analytics page. Can we sync tomorrow morning?"

No response. You check his last seen: 7:04 PM.

Saturday morning. He responds: "Sorry, I'm burned out. Worked 60 hours this week. Need weekend off. Can we fix Monday?"

signals.message: I know I said I'd be available but I can't anymore. Feeling exhausted. I'll fix it Monday, promise.
Just saw your message. I can look at backend side of analytics if it helps. But I'm also tired.
Planning to show analytics page to potential customer Monday afternoon. Sending them demo link Sunday night. Looking good?

weeks.situation: Maksym is burned out. David is sharing demo Monday. The feature is broken. You can't force Maksym to work weekends. But if David sends broken demo, it's your reputation.

options.title: Ask Maksym to work weekend
options.description: Apologize, but explain urgency, ask for 3-4 hours Saturday to fix critical issues.
options.shortConsequence: Might lose his trust or motivation long-term

consequences.immediate: You call Maksym, apologize, explain David is showing it Monday. He agrees reluctantly, works 4 hours Saturday. Bugs fixed. Demo works. But Maksym is resentful. Week 9: he's noticeably less engaged. Week 11: he tells you privately he's interviewing elsewhere. You might lose him post-launch.

options.title: Fix it yourself
options.description: You have some technical background. Spend Sunday fixing basic issues yourself.
options.shortConsequence: Overstepping role, might break something else

consequences.immediate: You spend 6 hours Sunday fixing frontend bugs. Fix 2 out of 3 issues. But accidentally break data formatting on another page. Maksym discovers this Monday morning, frustrated: "Why did you touch my code?" Demo works but team dynamic damaged. Maksym feels you don't trust him.

options.title: Tell David to delay demo share
options.description: Explain the feature needs Monday morning fixes, send link Monday afternoon instead.
options.shortConsequence: Honest, but David might lose trust in you

consequences.immediate: You call David Saturday evening, explain situation honestly. He's frustrated: "I told customer Sunday." You offer to send link Monday 2 PM instead. Customer is fine with it. Maksym fixes bugs Monday morning. Demo works. David appreciates honesty but notes you "couldn't deliver on time." Week 10: he double-checks your commitments.

options.title: Let it go
options.description: Send demo as-is, tell David "some features are in progress," manage expectations.
options.shortConsequence: David shows broken product to customer

consequences.immediate: David sends demo link Sunday night. Customer tests it Monday morning. Finds bugs. Responds: "Looks early stage, let's reconnect when it's more stable." David is embarrassed and angry. Blames you for not flagging issues. Trust severely damaged. Week 8-12: he micromanages everything.

weeks.title: The Integration Hell
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Told David the demo needs Monday morning polish. He wasn't happy but agreed. Maksym fixed the issues Monday. David sent demo link Monday afternoon. Customer responded positively.

But now integration phase starts. Stripe, CSV import, analytics engine ‚Äî everything needs to work together. Individually they work. Together, things break.

Wednesday. Yana posts: "Payment webhook triggers CSV import bug. Import fails silently. Lost two hours debugging this."

Thursday. Maksym: "When dashboard refreshes during import, data shows partial state. UX is confusing."

Friday. Andriy: "I have 47 open bugs. 23 are integration issues. I don't even know who owns them."

You realize you built features in isolation. Integration testing was "planned for later." It's later.

signals.message: This is why I said we need system design upfront. Now we're patching interactions we didn't consider.
I can't fix UI issues if backend behavior is unpredictable. We need stable APIs first.
I'm going to stop logging bugs and just focus on critical path. Otherwise I'm just documenting chaos.
Are we going to fix the UX issues or just ship broken flows? I need to know so I can adjust expectations.

weeks.situation: Integration debt is real. You have 4 weeks until demo. The product kind of works, but feels fragile. Team is frustrated. Everyone is blaming process, not people. You need a reset.

options.title: Integration sprint
options.description: Declare next week "integration week." No new features. Only cross-system fixes.
options.shortConsequence: Right call, but loses 1 week of feature development

consequences.immediate: You announce integration sprint. Team spends full week testing cross-feature scenarios and fixing. By Friday: 35 of 47 bugs fixed. Product feels stable. But you're now 1 week behind. Week 12: you'll have to demo without user management feature David wanted. He'll be disappointed but understands.

options.title: Prioritize critical path
options.description: Define 3-4 core user flows, make those bulletproof, ignore edge cases.
options.shortConsequence: Demo will work, but shallow coverage

consequences.immediate: You identify critical path: signup ‚Üí connect Stripe ‚Üí view dashboard ‚Üí export data. Team focuses only on these flows. By Week 12: these 4 flows work perfectly. But anything outside this path is broken. Demo impresses investors because you control the script. But product isn't truly ready for customers.

options.title: Divide and conquer
options.description: Yana fixes backend integration, Maksym fixes frontend, they don't block each other.
options.shortConsequence: Parallel work, but coordination overhead

consequences.immediate: Yana and Maksym work in parallel on integration fixes. Less blocking, but coordination issues. They fix same bug differently, creating conflicts. Spend 2 days in Week 9 resolving merge conflicts. Progress slower than expected. Week 12: still 15 integration bugs open.

options.title: Reduce scope retroactively
options.description: Remove CSV import from MVP, simplify product, reduce integration complexity.
options.shortConsequence: Loses feature David promised to customer

consequences.immediate: You propose cutting CSV import ‚Äî it's causing 60% of integration issues. David is shocked: "But I promised that customer!" You explain it's this or broken demo. He reluctantly agrees. Team relieved. Product simplifies. Integration bugs drop to 12. Week 12: customer asks about CSV, David has awkward conversation. Relationship strained.

weeks.title: The Demo Disaster
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Defined critical path: user signup ‚Üí connect Stripe ‚Üí view dashboard ‚Üí export data. Everything else is "nice to have." Team focused. Integration is improving.

It's Thursday. David scheduled internal demo tomorrow for the board. "Friendly run," he called it. Practice before investor demo in 3 weeks.

Friday 10 AM. Demo starts. You're screen-sharing. Five board members on the call. David introduces: "This is what we've built in 9 weeks."

You start demo. Signup works. Stripe connection... loading... still loading... error. Stripe API timeout.

You refresh. Try again. Works this time. Move to dashboard. It loads. But the numbers are wrong. Revenue shows $0 despite connected account having data.

David jumps in: "Ah, that's just test data. Moving on." But you see board members typing in chat to each other.

You continue. Export button. Click. Nothing happens. You click again. Page freezes.

Demo ends. David says: "We'll have it polished in 3 weeks." Board is silent.

signals.message: What happened? That was embarrassing. We have 3 weeks to fix this or we're dead.
Stripe timeout is intermittent. I've seen it twice this week but couldn't reproduce consistently.
Export bug is new. Worked yesterday. I'll investigate.
I flagged both issues in bug tracker. Stripe issue is marked 'low priority.' Export bug was found this morning.

weeks.situation: The demo was a disaster. David is panicking. Board lost confidence. You have 3 weeks. The product mostly works, but "mostly" isn't enough for an investor demo. You need perfect execution.

options.title: Feature freeze immediately
options.description: No new work. Only stability, bug fixes, demo rehearsals.
options.shortConsequence: Right call, but some planned features die

consequences.immediate: You declare feature freeze effective immediately. Maksym was halfway through settings page ‚Äî it stays unfinished. Team focuses entirely on stability for 3 weeks. By Week 12: demo runs perfectly, zero bugs. But product has fewer features than originally planned. Investors notice missing pieces. Still fund, but at lower valuation.

options.title: Rebuild critical path from scratch
options.description: Yana rewrites Stripe integration, Maksym rebuilds export, you test obsessively.
options.shortConsequence: Might fix root issues, but risky with 3 weeks left

consequences.immediate: Yana spends 1.5 weeks rewriting Stripe integration from scratch. It's cleaner but introduces new bugs. Week 11: you're still fixing issues from the rewrite. Demo day: it works, but barely. You stayed up 48 hours before demo fixing last-minute issues. Product works but team is destroyed.

options.title: Add monitoring and fallbacks
options.description: Keep features as-is, add error handling, retry logic, loading states.
options.shortConsequence: Doesn't fix bugs, just hides them better

consequences.immediate: You add retry logic to Stripe calls, better error messages, loading indicators. Bugs still exist but are less visible. Week 12 demo: Stripe timeout happens but system retries automatically and succeeds. Export occasionally fails but shows "Try again" button. Demo looks polished but product is still fragile underneath.

options.title: Hire external help
options.description: Bring in contractor for 2 weeks to fix critical bugs while team builds features.
options.shortConsequence: Costs money, coordination overhead, cultural tension

consequences.immediate: You hire senior contractor for $8K (eats into budget). He fixes Stripe and export bugs in 1 week. Efficient but team feels inadequate. Yana is offended: "We could've fixed this." Contractor introduces different coding patterns. Week 12: bugs are fixed but codebase is inconsistent. Post-demo: team has to refactor contractor's code.

weeks.title: The Midnight Message
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Feature freeze. David agreed reluctantly. Team is in full bug-fix mode. Andriy is testing every flow. Maksym is fixing frontend issues. Yana is stabilizing backend. Olena is polishing UI inconsistencies.

It's Tuesday night. 11:47 PM. You're in bed. Phone buzzes. Slack message. Yana: "We have a problem."

You open laptop. She continues: "Stripe changed their webhook format last week. I just found out. Our integration is broken for new accounts. Existing ones work. But any new signup after last Thursday gets wrong data."

You check. She's right. Stripe docs show API v2 migration. You're on v1. They deprecated it.

Yana: "I can migrate to v2. But it's 3-4 days of work. And might break existing accounts during transition."

It's 12:03 AM. Demo is in 13 days. You have a critical integration rewrite needed.

signals.message: I should have caught this earlier. But their changelog is buried. I only found it because I was debugging why test account behaved differently.

signals.time: (offline, but you know he'll panic if you tell him in the morning)

weeks.situation: Yana found a critical issue at midnight. She's offering to fix it, but it's risky. You could keep current integration and hope demo uses old account. Or migrate and risk breaking everything days before demo.

options.title: Migrate to v2 immediately
options.description: Yana starts tomorrow, works through weekend if needed, you block out 4 days for this.
options.shortConsequence: Right long-term, but risky short-term

consequences.immediate: Yana works Thursday-Sunday migrating to v2. Saturday afternoon: migration breaks existing accounts. Panic. Sunday night at 11 PM: she fixes it. Monday: everything works on v2, future-proof. But team is exhausted. Demo prep delayed by 3 days. Week 11: rushed final testing. Demo day: works but you had no buffer for issues.

options.title: Patch v1 to work
options.description: Find workaround to make v1 functional for demo, migrate after investor meeting.
options.shortConsequence: Technical debt, but safer for demo

consequences.immediate: Yana builds hacky workaround in 1 day ‚Äî manually converts v1 to v2 format before processing. Works for demo. Post-demo Week 13: you have to do proper v2 migration. But investors funded you, so you have time. The workaround becomes permanent for 3 months. Eventually causes production incident.

options.title: Use existing account for demo
options.description: Don't fix it. Demo only with pre-migration account. Hope investors don't test signup.
options.shortConsequence: Demo works, but product is broken for new users

consequences.immediate: You decide to demo with existing Stripe account (still on v1). Demo day: works perfectly. Investors impressed. They fund you. Week 13: first real customer tries to signup. Breaks. They churn. You spend 2 weeks firefighting v2 migration post-funding. Your launch is delayed. Early adopters frustrated.

options.title: Tell David now
options.description: Wake him up (or message for morning), let him decide since it's business-critical.
options.shortConsequence: Escalates decision, but might create panic

consequences.immediate: You message David at 12:30 AM. He wakes up, calls you at 1 AM. Panics. Wants to migrate. Then changes mind. Then panics again. By 3 AM you have no decision. Morning: he decides to keep v1 for demo. But your midnight escalation made him lose confidence in your judgment. Week 11-12: he micromanages everything.

weeks.title: The Final Push
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Yana built a workaround. It's hacky. It works. Stripe v2 migration is postponed to post-demo. David doesn't know the full story. He just knows "it's fixed."

It's the final week before demo. Monday. Team is in war room mode. Every day you run full demo rehearsal. Every evening you find issues. Every night someone fixes them.

Wednesday. Demo is Friday. David is rehearsing his pitch. You're rehearsing the product. Everything is working. Finally.

Thursday morning. Andriy runs final test. Finds new bug. Not critical. But visible. When user disconnects Stripe, old data remains in dashboard. Looks like the disconnect didn't work.

Maksym says: "I can fix it in 3 hours." Yana says: "But we'll need to redeploy. And retesting takes 2 hours. We have 24 hours until demo."

David walks by: "Everything ready?"

signals.message: This bug won't stop demo. But if investor disconnects and reconnects Stripe during demo, they'll see stale data.
I can fix it. But do we deploy 12 hours before demo? That's the question.
I vote no. We're stable now. Don't touch production before demo.
From UX perspective, it's confusing. But not demo-breaking. I'd leave it.

weeks.situation: Minor bug. Easy fix. But deploying day before demo is risky. If something breaks during deployment, you have no buffer. But if investor hits this bug during demo, it looks unpolished.

options.title: Fix and deploy now
options.description: Maksym fixes, you deploy Thursday afternoon, test all evening.
options.shortConsequence: Clean product, but risk of deployment issues

consequences.immediate: Maksym fixes bug in 2 hours. You deploy at 3 PM. Testing starts. 6 PM: discover deployment broke dashboard loading for Safari. Panic. Maksym and Yana work until 2 AM fixing it. Friday morning at 8 AM: finally stable. Demo at 2 PM: works but team is zombies. You pulled all-nighter for minor bug.

options.title: Don't touch anything
options.description: Leave the bug, brief David, tell him to avoid disconnect flow in demo.
options.shortConsequence: Stable, but requires demo choreography

consequences.immediate: You tell David: "Don't disconnect Stripe during demo." He nods. Demo day: goes perfectly. Investors never try disconnect. Funding secured. Post-demo: you fix bug in Week 13. Right decision. Team appreciates you prioritized stability over perfection. Yana later tells you: "That was the right call."

options.title: Fix but don't deploy
options.description: Maksym fixes in code, you deploy Monday after demo, keeps production untouched.
options.shortConsequence: Doesn't help demo, but you feel productive

consequences.immediate: Maksym spends Thursday fixing code in development branch. You don't deploy. Demo day: bug still there. Investor tries disconnect flow. Sees stale data. Asks: "Is this supposed to stay?" David improvises: "That's a feature for audit trail." Investor skeptical but doesn't block funding. You got lucky.

options.title: Let David decide
options.description: Present both options, make it his call since it's his demo.
options.shortConsequence: Passes responsibility, but might stress him out

consequences.immediate: You present both options to David. He freezes. Can't decide. Asks you: "What would you do?" You're back to square one. He finally says: "Let's fix it." You deploy. But his indecision wasted 3 hours. Deploy happens at 6 PM instead of 3 PM. Less testing time. Demo day: works, but was unnecessarily stressful.

weeks.title: The Demo
weeks.context:
You chose your path last week. Didn't deploy the fix. Briefed David: avoid Stripe disconnect in demo. He nodded.

It's Friday. 2 PM. Investor demo. Eight people on Zoom. David is presenting. You're running the product. Maksym and Yana are on standby in another room, just in case.

David introduces the problem Subflow solves. Explains the market. Shows competitor weaknesses. Then: "Let me show you what we built."

You share screen. Demo starts. Signup flow ‚Äî perfect. Stripe connection ‚Äî loads smoothly. Dashboard ‚Äî data appears. Numbers are correct. Export ‚Äî works. CSV import ‚Äî uploads without error. Analytics page ‚Äî charts render.

It's working. Everything is working.

David shows different views. Filters. Date ranges. All smooth. Investors are nodding. One asks: "Can you show user management?" You freeze. User management wasn't built.

David pivots: "That's in the next sprint. For MVP, we focused on core analytics." Investor accepts it.

Demo ends. 15 minutes. No crashes. No freezes. No bugs.

David closes with roadmap. Call ends. He messages you: "We did it."

An hour later. Lead investor emails David: "Impressive progress. We're in for Series B. Let's talk terms next week."

signals.message: I can't believe it worked. Thank you. Seriously. I know this was brutal.
Wait, we got Series B? After all that chaos? Wow.
I'm going to sleep for 48 hours. But yeah, we did it. Feels unreal.
The product is not what I envisioned. But it worked when it mattered. I guess that's enough.

weeks.situation: The demo succeeded. Series B is happening. The team is relieved. But you know the product is held together with duct tape. Stripe v2 migration is pending. Bugs are logged but unfixed. Integration issues are hidden, not resolved. David will want to start aggressive feature development next week. The team needs rest. The codebase needs refactoring.

options.title: Push for stabilization sprint
options.description: Tell David the team needs 2 weeks to clean up tech debt before Series B acceleration.
options.shortConsequence: Right call, but he might see it as slowing momentum

consequences.immediate: You tell David: "We need 2 weeks to fix what we postponed." He's resistant: "But we have momentum!" You explain technical debt reality. He reluctantly agrees to 1 week. Team grateful but still exhausted. Week 13-14: you fix critical issues. Week 15: aggressive feature development starts. Team somewhat recovered. Codebase cleaner. Sustainable pace.

options.title: Ride the momentum
options.description: Start building next features immediately, deal with tech debt "later."
options.shortConsequence: Team burns out, debt compounds

consequences.immediate: David announces new features starting Monday. Team groans internally but complies. Week 13: Maksym calls in sick (burnout). Week 14: Critical bug in production from postponed Stripe migration. Week 15: Yana gives notice. Technical debt becomes unmanageable. By Month 4: you're rebuilding entire system. Momentum killed by burnout.

options.title: Negotiate hybrid
options.description: 1 week rest, 1 week cleanup, then aggressive growth.
options.shortConsequence: Compromise, but might not be enough rest

consequences.immediate: You propose: Week 13 off, Week 14 cleanup, Week 15 new features. David agrees. Team takes vacation. Returns refreshed. Week 14: fix most critical debt. Week 15: start new features at sustainable pace. Not perfect but manageable. Team stays intact. Codebase improvable. Sustainable for 6+ months.

options.title: Let team decide
options.description: Ask Yana, Maksym, Olena, Andriy what they need. Trust their judgment.
options.shortConsequence: Empowering, but they might say what you want to hear

consequences.immediate: You ask team what they need. Maksym: "Honestly? 2 weeks off." Yana: "1 week rest, 1 week fixing my hacks." Olena: "Just acknowledgment this wasn't sustainable." Andriy: "Clear backlog so I can start fresh." You present this to David. He's moved by their honesty. Agrees to 2 weeks. Team loyalty skyrockets. They return energized.

finalReview.outcomeText:
The MVP launched. The demo worked. Series B funding secured.

But the product you showed wasn't the product in production. You demonstrated core flows under controlled conditions. Investors saw potential, not reality.

The team delivered the impossible. They worked nights. They skipped quality steps. They built workarounds instead of solutions. They said yes when they meant "maybe if we're lucky."

The hidden cost: technical debt that will take 3 months to unwind. A team that trusts you but is exhausted. A codebase that works but nobody fully understands anymore. A founder who thinks you can do this again, faster.
finalReview.reflectionText:
Not the conference talk version. The real one.

You didn't fail. But you didn't win cleanly either.

You made twelve decisions. Most were reasonable in isolation. But decisions compound. Each trade-off borrowed from the future. Each "yes" to speed was a "no" to stability.

The team doesn't blame you. They delivered what you asked. They trust you. But trust is a resource too. And you've spent it.

Next phase starts Monday. David expects acceleration. The team expects rest. The codebase expects refactoring. You can't give everyone what they need.

And that's the truth nobody puts in the retrospective.
